The Claremore, OK Waste Water Treatment Plant (WWTP) is owned and maintained by the City of Claremore, OK. However, the City of Claremore, OK has full legal responsibility for the WWTP including the authority to make all policy and procedure decisions for this facility.  



The City of Claremore, OK has contracted day to day operations and maintenance to Inframark.  All decisions concerning the Risk Management Program for this facility shall be made by the City of Claremore, OK or their duly appointed liaison with input from the Inframark RMP Manager and on-site operations personnel. 



1.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Although there are no active or passive mitigation systems in place at this facility which could limit the effects of an accidental chemical release, the plant employs a number of different programs and policies to prevent an accidental release.  These are detailed in the various sections of the RMP manual but include the following:



Safety Information

Safety information for the chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide system must be maintained as part of this prevention program. The Safety Data Sheets (SDS) for chlorine and sulfur dioxide are included. The SDSs provide information about each of the regulated substance including chemical characteristics, reactivity data, physical hazards, toxicity hazards, exposure limits, thermal and chemical stability, corrosive data, precautions for safe handling and emergency and first aid procedures. An understanding of the characteristics of chlorine and sulfur dioxide are essential to ensuring safe handling of these toxic substances.  Other pertinent safety information for chlorine and sulfur dioxide can be found in the plan. 



Specifications for the chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide system components include the crane system. The specifications also include material and design information on the vessels, piping and process equipment used for chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage and

distribution at the facility. 



Operating Procedures

Written operating procedures which give instructions for safely conducting activities for each phase of operation, are incorporated as part of this Risk Management Program. 

The phases of operation include: 

?  initial startup, 

?  normal operations, 

?  emergency shutdown, 

?  emergency operations, 

?  temporary operations, startup following a turnaround, 

?  operating limits, and 

?  normal shutdown. 



Training

Proper training is essential to ensure safe operation of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide equipment and processes. The training program must include either hands-on or classroom instruction and appropriate competency testing. Training covers, at a minimum, the connecting and disconnecting of cylinders, including visual inspections and the use of tools, and operation of cylinder handling equipment. All operations personnel responsible for the PLANT must have refresher-training at least annually.



The training program will include:

  Risk Management Program

  Cl2 and/or SO2 Equipment and Process Safety

  Cl2 and/or SO2 Operating Procedures

  Cl2 and/or SO2 Maintenance Procedures

  Emergency Response Program

  General Safety 



Mechanical Integrity Program

Preventative maintenance, inspection and testing of equipment are critical to safe operations, including crane and hoist system and scales. Preventative maintenance includes written procedures and schedules of maintenance, safety training of equipment operators and inspection of equipment per manufactures recommendations.  



2.0    STATIONARY SOURCE



The plant is located at 1500 S. Choctaw, Claremore, OK and utilizes chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide. Chlorine is used for disinfection and sulfur dioxide neutralizes the chlorine before discharge.  The plant has the capacity to store approximately 8,000 pounds (lbs.) of chlorine and/or 8,000 pounds (lbs.) of sulfur dioxide on-site at any one time. Both chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide at

the facility are contained in -ton containers that are on a standby/on-line basis to ensure the chlorination/neutralization process is continuous. Chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide are drawn from the 1-ton containers in a gaseous state.

Chlorine and/or Sulfur Dioxide are stored as a liquid chemical in the 1-ton cylinder containers. However, as space is created inside the container by use of the chemical, a vapor forms to fill the void space, creating a two-phase chemical storage with the chlorine being present in both liquid and vapor form. 



4.0    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The general accidental release prevention program includes the following:



  Process safety information

  Process hazard analysis

  Operating procedures

  Training

  Mechanical integrity

  Management of change

  Pre-startup review

  Compliance audits

  Incident investigation

  Employee participation

  Hot work permit

  Contractor management



Chemical-specific prevention steps can be found in the operating procedures and elsewhere. 



5.0    OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS -   WORST CASE SCENARIO



A worst-case scenario for an accidental chemical release has been developed for the plant. The worst-case release quantity of a regulated substance

is defined in 40 CFR ?68 as the greatest amount held in a single vessel or in a pipe. Therefore, at the PLANT the worst-case release quantity, as defined by the EPA, is considered to be one (1) - 2,000-pound cylinder of chlorine (Cl2) or sulfur dioxide (SO2).  Worst case scenario and off-site consequences analysis are included in the plan.



Toxic Endpoint

A toxic endpoint is defined as the "maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals can be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action". According to EPA guidelines, the toxic endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/L (3 ppm) and is 0.0078 mg/L (3ppm) for sulfur dioxide.



Chlorine Release

The distance to the toxic endpoint for chlorine is determined using the EPA guidelines presented in the "Risk Management Guide for Offsite Consequences Analysis". The worst-case scenario assumes that the entire quantity of a single vessel would be released over a period of 10 minutes. For a 2,000-pound vessel, this calculates to a release rate of 200-lb/min. Other factors are taken into consideration in the determination of a toxic endpoint, including the terrain of the surrounding area (rural or urban), typical weather conditions and chemical density. The following factors were used in ?the calculation of the toxic endpoint for this facility: Wind speed 1.5 m/s; Atmospheric Stability Class F; Temperature 25?; Humidity 50%; Urban Surface Roughness; Height of release 0-feet (ground level). For wastewater treatment plants, chlorine and sulfur dioxide are always assumed to be dense gases which travel close to the ground surface. An urban surface roughness was chosen because there are many obstacles in the path of potential release, including trees and structures.



The worst-case scenario for the plant was developed using the EPA's screening tool RMP*CO

MP, and the distance to a toxic endpoint for chlorine in an urban area is  1.3 miles at a release rate of 200-lb/min. A map showing the toxic endpoint radius around the plant is included in the plan.



Sulfur Dioxide Release 

The distance to the toxic endpoint for sulfur dioxide is determined using the EPA guidelines presented in the "Risk Management Guide for Offsite Consequences Analysis". The worst-case scenario assumes that the entire quantity of a single vessel would be released over a period of 10 minutes. For a 2,000-pound vessel, this calculates to a release rate of 200-lb/min. Other factors are taken into consideration in the determination of a toxic endpoint, including the terrain of the surrounding area (rural or urban), typical weather conditions and chemical density. The following factors were used in ?the calculation of the toxic endpoint for this facility: Wind speed 1.5 m/s; Atmospheric Stability Class F; Temperature 25?; Humidity 50%; Urban Surface Roughness; Height of release 0-feet (ground level). For wastewater treatment plants, chlorine and sulfur dioxide are always assumed to be dense gases which travel close to the ground surface. An urban surface roughness was chosen because there are many obstacles in the path of potential release, including trees and structures.



The worst-case scenario for the plant was developed using the EPA approved RMP*COMP and the distance to a toxic endpoint for sulfur dioxide in an urban area is 1.3 miles at a release rate of 200-lb/min. A map showing the toxic endpoint radius around the plant is included in the plan.



6.0    OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS - ALTERNATIVE SCENARIO



Alternative release scenarios have been developed for the plant. According to EPA requirements, an alternative scenario must be developed for each toxic substance held above the threshold quantity for a facility with multiple toxic substances on-site.



The EPA guidelines require evaluation of potential various scenarios that may be mor

e realistic in occurring at the plant as an alternative scenario.  The below scenarios were considered as part of the evaluation:

?  Scenario 1 - Transfer releases due to spills or sudden hose uncoupling considered and not completed as the system is under vacuum and will shut system down.

?  Scenario 2 - Process piping releases from failures at flanges joints, welds, valves and valve seals and drain or bleed considered and not completed for same reason as scenario 1.

?  Scenario 3 - Process vessel or pump releases due to cracks, seal failure, or drain, bleed or plug failure considered but not selected because vessels are inspected on receipt and not put in service if there are deficiencies.

?  Scenario 4 - Vessel overfilling and spill, or over pressurization and venting through relief valves or rupture disks considered and not selected because Inframark does not fill the tanks.

?  Scenario 5 - Shipping container mishandling and breakage or puncture leading to a spill considered and selected as most likely to cause a release.



An alternative scenario is described as a release event that reaches an endpoint offsite and is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario. There have not been any offsite release incidents at the which could be referenced as an alternative scenario. Therefore, default conditions as suggested by the EPA Risk Management Plan guidelines were used to determine the alternative release scenarios for chlorine and sulfur dioxide. The EPA default weather conditions for the alternative release scenarios differ slightly from those used in the worst-case scenario analysis. The alternative scenario uses an atmospheric stability class D and a wind speed of 3 m/s.



Alternative case scenario and off-site consequences analysis are included in the plan.



Alternative Release Scenario - Chlorine

For the plant alternative chlorine release scenario, it is assumed that a release from ? inch hole in liquid phase of the tank caused by mishandling st

orage vessel.  Using US EPA Risk Management Guidance for Chemical Distributors and default conditions for an urban area, it is determined a chlorine release rate of 160 lbs./min. for 12.5 minutes releasing the full contents of the tank.  The toxic endpoint is determined to be 0.2 miles



All offsite receptors will be identified on the map as related to the alternative case scenario.  The offsite consequences analysis is included in the plan.  



Alternative Release Scenario - Sulfur Dioxide

For the plant alternative sulfur dioxide release scenario, it is assumed that a release from ? inch hole in liquid phase of the tank caused by mishandling storage vessel.  Using US EPA Risk Management Guidance for Chemical Distributors and default conditions for an urban area, it is determined a chlorine release rate of 160 lbs./min. for 12.5 minutes releasing the full contents of the tank.  The toxic endpoint is determined to be 0.2 miles and is shown on the map included in the plan. 



As discussed in the Offsite Consequence Analysis for the worst-case scenario, there are no active mitigation systems at this facility, which could limit the effects of an accidental chemical release, additionally the offsite receptors will be identified and mapped.  



All offsite receptors will be identified on the map as related to the alternative case scenario.  The offsite consequences analysis is included in the plan.  



7.0    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



As of the publication date of this Risk Management Program there have not been any accidental releases of which caused any on-site or offsite deaths, injuries or property damage at the plant during the past five years.  A statement of assurance from the Inframark RMP Manager regarding accidental releases at the Plant during the past five years is included in the plan.



An incident investigation will be completed and prepared for each accidental release that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted, in a catastrophic release of

a regulated substance. The incident investigation report must be retained for a period of five years following the incident. A catastrophic release is classified as having caused at least one of the following:



  On-site deaths, injuries or significant property damage (?68.42a) or

  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42a).



The RMP Manager is designated as the responsible party to conduct the required accidental release investigation and complete the appropriate documentation. Additionally, the RMP Manager must make all required notifications for an accidental spill. The RMP Manager must maintain copies of all incident investigation documents at the plant.



8.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Emergency Response Program (ERP) is an important element of the Inframark RMP program.   The purpose of the ERP is to ensure that proper preparation, response, recovery, and consequence mitigation procedures are in place for accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide resulting from natural disaster, human error, equipment failure, or sabotage.  The goals of this program include the following:

  Protect the public's health and the environment.

  Protect the health of facility staff and contract employees.

  Protect the health of local emergency response agency personnel.

  Coordinate emergency response actions between the local emergency response agencies and facility staff.

  Provide emergency response procedures to be followed by facility personnel during emergency situations.



There are no facilities employees designated or qualified to respond to an uncontrolled release of a hazardous substance; therefore, the plant would be considered a non-responding facility by EPA standards. An incidental release which does not cause a potential safety or health hazard or that can be neutralized or controlled at the time of release by an on-site operator would not be considered an uncontr

olled release of a hazardous substance. An Emergency Response Plan is in place at the facility to address incidental releases. 



The chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage area are monitored by vapor detection units, which notify the facility operations company by auto-dialer in the event of an accidental release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide. Additionally, an alarm and flashing light system alert on-site personnel to the presence of a chemical release.



Response coordination efforts have been made with the local Fire Department and Local Emergency Planning Commission. 



9.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



At this time there are no new renovations/projects planned however, any significant change in the processes or equipment at the plant shall trigger an update of the Safety Information included as part of the Risk Management Program.
